descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores the role of gender and sexuality in creating, sustaining, and undermining empires in the eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth centuries. We will ask how and why controlling the intimate lives of colonizers and colonized became such a fundamental part of the imperial project. How did colonizing and colonized notions of gender and sexuality come into contact and conflict? How did ideas about sexuality shape racial thinking in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries and what was the fallout of this way of thought in the twentieth? How did independence movements harness and alter imperial ideas about gender and sexuality to overthrow colonial powers? Drawing on primary texts as well as historical monographs and the scholarship of gender and sexuality, we will investigate how empires were built around interlocking ideas about sexuality, gender, class, and race.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Discussion (20%), Two Quizzes (10% each), & Three Source Analysis Papers (20% each)
